Entries.default: "What... why are you- ? What is this room?"
"Vatnir, Vatnir! The messenger has fall - Duskspeaker?!"
"Your priest here is a faithless coward who hid when the dragon came."
"Yes. We were deep in discourse. Very deep."
[Say nothing.]
"First the messenger, now Vatnir?! Is nothing sacred to you?"
"Vatnir was faithless. He manipulated you to his own ends."
"Rymrgand did not intend for his child to live forever."
[Attack] "He certainly wasn't. And neither are you."
"I... I'm to guide the Duskspeaker to the Vytmádh, brother. I know not how long I shall be gone."
"What he said."
"Your priest here is a faithless coward who hid when the dragon came."
[Say nothing.]

"Well, you see, uh, I was - ahem - we were just discussing some matters of orthodoxy."

The godlike's three tightly-clumped eyes swivel towards you nervously.
"If you're not here, though, who's to guide the Harbingers?"
"I leave that in your able hands, brother. I promise to return quickly."
"But, uh, Rymrgand's messenger has fallen... what should we do now?"
"Survive and keep our work going. The Duskspeaker and I will set everything aright. I swear it."

"I'm not faithless. I just, perhaps, I saw the, the teachings must..."

He coughs violently, shaking his head.

"What ridiculousness! Do you think us fools?"

Arms crossed, the hooded figure scowls at you. You think.
"He let you believe that the dragon out there was a chosen messenger of Rymrgand. Now it's dead."
"Look around you. He had a secret room. What else was he hiding?"
"You dare question the Duskspeaker?"

"Oh, uh, okay."

His hooded head shifts its focus from Vatnir to you and back again.
"I should probably get back to the surface. To do... surface things."
"I, you see, I invited the Duskspeaker into my... chamber of contemplation. Which is isolated. So that I can, we can, contemplate in it."
"Just seems a bit strange's all. With the hidden room and everything."
"Which of us is the Beast of Winter's chosen?"
"What? Wait! You, of course! You are, and I'm not questioning that!"
"Where is Vatnir?"
"Rymrgand has tasked Vatnir in helping me investigate this dragon."
"I've asked him to help me find the truth about this dragon. He agreed."
"But, with you having killed the messenger, and with Vatnir helping you, what are the rest of us to do?"
"Rymrgand has everything under control. Just try not to sink this place into the sea until we return."
"You should worry less about what the gods want, and more about what you need."
"Rymrgand's not here to make every little decision for you. You're going to have to figure this one out on your own."
"Everything will be fine, Hafjórn. Lead the Harbingers in Vatnir's absence. I believe in you."

"Oh? Incredible! Truly, this day is blessed!"

But then Hafjórn's gaze falls to the floor.
"I don't suppose the Beast of Winter told you what we Harbingers should do next?"
Through the holes in his sagging, sweat-stained hood, you make out the rapid fluttering of Hafjórn's eyes.

"Of course, Duskspeaker! We will persist until the Beast sees fit to end us!"

He straightens, rapping a closed fist against his sternum.

"Thank you, Duskspeaker. I swear I'll prove worthy of your faith!"

He straightens, shoulders back.
"What? But you're the Dusk- I don't understa- Oh. Oh. Of course, we can't serve the faith if we don't survive to do so."
"What? Oh, I, I suppose you're right. The Beast of Winter, he expects self-sufficiency. I'll tell the others about Vatnir."
"That is a little strange, I suppose." He stares at the floor.
"A good question. Why hide this from us?" Hafjórn looks around the room.
"He would not! I have known Vatnir for dozens of years! He is wise! Very intelligent!"
"I'll - I'll admit him a far walk from perfect, that's for certain. Couldn't hunt a bear to save his life."
The pale elves recoil from you. Vatnir cringes, and Hafjórn raises a pair of placating palms.
"He told me that he used his status as a godlike to manipulate you into helping him leave the White that Wends."
"I get the impression Vatnir may have given you plenty of reason to doubt him."

"Enough! Enough..."

As the large elf sighs his head falls forward and shoulders slump.
"What you say, it makes a kind of sense. Vatnir, you will come with me, to explain yourself to the others."

"I should... I suppose I should tell the others. We'll, we will need to find him."

Hafjórn deflates with a sigh.
"Do whatever it is you came here to do, Duskspeaker. Perhaps you truly do carry the touch of winter."
"It comes and goes from the Vytmádh! It's clearly a creature of death!"
"That's odd. He was just here."
"You dare question the Duskspeaker?"
"You dare question the Duskspeaker?"
"You dare question the Dustspeaker?"
"I found him like this!"
"So you killed him? How are we to know you're not lying to us?"
"Look around you. He had a secret room. What else was he hiding?"
"He let you believe that the dragon out there was a chosen messenger of Rymrgand. Now it's dead."
"I get the impression Vatnir may have given you plenty of reason to doubt him."
"Lest you forget, I am the Duskspeaker. I came here to end things."
"I don't much care what you think."
"But - but that doesn't mean he was supposed to die now!"
He recoils as if struck, stumbling a few steps back before groping at his side for his blade.
"To arms, Harbingers! Rymrgand's chosen is slain!"

"I, oh, uh, of course, Duskspeaker. I... praise be to Rymrgand. To the Beast of Winter."

He audibly swallows.
Hafjórn stiffens, his hand reaching to his side for his weapon.
Hafjórn's hooded face turns away as the Harbinger rubs the back of his head.

"I'll - I'll admit him a far walk from perfect, that's for certain. Couldn't hunt a bear to save his life."

He peers down at the cooling corpse and sighs.
"But what are we supposed to do now?"
"You're asking us? I suppose it would be too much to ask of you to take responsibility for your own futures."
"By your hand!"
"The Beast of Winter would have us sweep away these falsehoods - prophets and avatars alike."
"Between that and the secret room, there's not much left in Vatnir to put stock in."
Hafjórn's hooded face turns away as the Harbinger rubs the back of his head.
"Hard to say, now, isn't it? What with him a corpse and all."
"Wish we could've asked him, though."
"That's, I guess that's the truth of it. I suppose. Praise the Beast."
"How about I make a substantial contribution to your temple to help you get your bearings again?"
"You'd... you'd offer me a bribe?"
Hafjórn's hooded face turns away as the Harbinger rubs the back of his head.
"Damnation! I'd rather your words didn't make sense, but I can't deny them."
"He was, in fact. Rymrgand himself told me to kill Vatnir."
"The Beast of Winter would have us sweep away these falsehoods - prophets and avatars alike."

"He did? But Vatnir was his chosen, too... And yet, nothing lives forever. Not even the Beast of Winter."

His hooded head sags.
"You think us fools? Ignorant savages who can't thresh a lie from a truth?"
"But, then, who could have done this? Everyone loves Vatnir! They respect him! He speaks for the Beast of Winter!"
"Oldest tale in the book, captain."

"I, oh, uh, of course, Duskspeaker. I... praise be to Rymrgand. To the Beast of Winter."

He audibly swallows.
"Perhaps the Beast of Winter tests you. His will manifests through exactly this kind of trial."
[Attack] "Enough of this."
Hafjórn's hooded face turns away as the Harbinger rubs the back of his head.
"I can't fault that thinking, I suppose."
Behind their lenses, Ydwin's eyes roll.
"Duskspeaker."
"Duskspeaker."

"What? No, of course not! I just, well, apologies and, uh, nevermind."

Hafjórn cringes.
"You dare question the Duskspeaker?"

"What? No, of course not! I just, well, apologies and, uh, nevermind."

Hafjórn cringes.
Hafjórn cranes his hooded head to either side, as if he might find Vatnir hiding in the corners of the small room.
"You could perhaps try having a thought of your own, brother."
"I've no idea why."
Ydwin pinches the bridge of her nose.
Hafjórn's hooded head turns uncertainly between the two of you.
"We're going to stop this iceberg from spreading across the Deadfire while there's still something to be done about it."
"Gods! You said - !"
[Attack] "Enough of this."
"My - my skill with bow and spear is not at question here!"
"Indeed it is not."

"That's true. Even if, well, Vatnir, he could be wrong, without er, being the charlatan you claim." 

Hafjórn rubs the back of his hooded head.
"By your hand!"
"Exactly. By my hand, Rymrgand's messenger died. That doesn't strike you as strange?"
"Have you ever heard any tale associating Rymrgand with dragons? I haven't."
[Say nothing.]
"It's not secret. It's not hidden. I just hadn't... told anyone about it."
"Not every rite of Rymrgand is for the entire clan to see!"
"Of- of course not! But, is not Vatnir chosen of Rymrgand as well?"
"Stop it? But why? It's the breath of winter!"
"Explain it to him, Vatnir."
"I prefer my beaches warm and sunny."
"You may be okay with destroying an entire archipelago, but I'm not going to let that happen!"
"I still need him to lead me to the temple."
"He can make up for his falsehoods by accompanying me."
"Take him away."
[Say nothing.]
"To Hel with all of you!" A coughing fit rattles Vatnir as he ducks past you.
"You had your chance!"
"I'll do nothing of the sort!"
"It is what Rymrgand has decreed!"
"Really? I suppose if anyone should know his will..."
"A Deadfire without beaches is not a Deadfire worth saving." Tekēhu folds his arms and represses a shiver.
"Everything shall unfold according to design, Hafjórn. You need worry not."
"What? Me? But you're... ugh!" He rubs the side of his bandaged head.
Hafjórn nods, his shoulders falling slightly as he visibly relaxes.
"Probably someone jealous of his authority. Or maybe someone who hates godlikes."
"I see there's no convincing you, blinded as you are by your faith."
As Hafjórn rubs the back of his head in confusion, Vatnir's three uncovered eyes narrow upon you.
"Go, Duskspeaker. Do your work. While time remains to do it."
"Go, Duskspeaker. Do your work. While time remains to do it."
"I shall not accompany you." He shakes his head and waves you away.
